If sales volume does go up another option would be other service markets for real estate such as real estate information and marketing websites and sources i.e. http://www.trulia.com. Furthermore one can go and make a broad generalization such as since real estate no longer requires the same quantity of construction material other industries sensitive to the price of those commodities should technically have a lower cost of doing business. But be careful in the US much of the wealth an average american has is in their home. In this case this means that the economy as a whole takes a dive due to consumer uncertainty. In which case safe havens could benefit, may be things like Proctor & Gamble, gold, or treasuries. Side Note: You can always short builders or someone who loses if the housing market declines, this will make your investment higher as a result of the security going lower.

"During the actual decline, there's very little money to be made and a lot to lose. When housing prices tank, everybody loses; the banks are exposed to higher risk of mortgage defaults, insurers start having to pay out more for ""gas leaks"" claiming over-leveraged homes,    realtors starve because their commissions go down (even as foreclosures put more homes on the market) and people faced with financial uncertainty will stay put in their current homes instead of moving elsewhere. And homebuilders and contractors go broke because nobody wants to spend cash on a new home or major reno that looks like a losing investment. There can be some bright spots. Smaller hardware stores will make money as people do relatively small DIY projects to improve the condition of their current home. The larger stores get this business too, but it tends to be more than offset by the loss of contractor business (FAR more lucrative, and something the ACEs and True-Values don't really get in on). Of course the ""grave-robbers"" do well; gold buyers, auctioneers, pawn shops, repo firms; these guys eat well when other people are defaulting on loans or have to sell their stuff for fast cash. Most of these businesses are not publicly traded. One thing that was seen was increased revenues at discount retailers like Wal-Mart, Dollar General etc. When things are bad, people in the middle class who had avoided these stores for image or morality reasons learn to swallow their pride and buy discount store brands for half the price of national brand names. That lessens the blow felt by the discount retailers as overall consumer spending decreases; the pie shrinks, but the discount retailers get a bigger slice of the mandatory spending on food, clothing, etc (and the higher-level retailers get it in the shorts). When the pie starts to grow again as consumer spending picks back up, the discount retailers retain their percentage for a while, as the fickle middle class can afford to buy more from the discount retailer but can't yet afford to take their business back to the shopping mall stores. This produces a flatter, ""offset"" price graph for discount retailers through the business cycle; they don't lose as early or as much as everyone else in a major downturn, and they turn it around sooner while everyone else may still be on the way down, but as everything gets better for everyone on the upswing it's less great for the discount guys, as they start losing customers and their dollars to competitors with better stuff, even as the ones they keep spend more. This doesn't generally manifest as a true negative correlation, but it can be a good hedge. The number one money-making investment in a tanking economy is gold. When things go down the crapper, everyone wants gold, so if you see the train wreck coming far enough in advance, you can make a big move to gold and really make some money off that investment. For instance, when the first whispers about ARM adjustments and mass defaults reached the public consciousness in mid-2005, gold bullion jumped from about $400 to over $700 in a nine-month period. It cooled off again in 06-07 but only to about $600/oz, and then in late 07 it steadily climbed to peak at $1000/oz; even if you got in late, an investment of $1000 in July '07 in ""bulk"" gold would have netted you $650 in one year; that's a 65% APY. Then the economy hit bottom and a lot of investors ditched gold for investments they thought would pull back out of their holes quickly; For just a little while in '08 gold was down to $700 again. Then came all the government reports; unemployment not budging, home prices still declining, a lot of banks still hiding just how bad their position was. If you had seen that it was going to be bad, bad, bad, like a lot of now-billionaire hedge fund investors did, a $1000 investment in gold in July 05, and then cashing out at the tops of the peaks and buying back in at the major troughs, would be worth almost $4000 today. That's a 400% return over 7 years, or an annual average yield of 57%. There simply hasn't been anything like that in the last 7 years."

question: Tax consequences of changing state residency?
answer:
Changing your state residency can have various tax consequences, and the impact largely depends on the tax laws of the states involved. Here are some key points to consider:

1. Income Earned Before and After Moving: When you move from one state to another and also change your work location, all income earned before the date you establish residency in the new state is considered income for your old state (State 1). All income on or after that date is considered income for your new state (State 2). It's important to clearly establish your new residency if there is a significant difference in income or tax rates between the two states .

2. Tax Rates and Residency: If you move from a state with high taxes to a state with low taxes, you should take steps to establish your residency in the new state by registering your vehicles, registering to vote, and getting a new driver's license. The move can impact your tax situation and your financial planning .

3. Work Location vs. Residency: If you move your home to a new state but continue to work in your previous state, the question of where you pay tax can become more complex. Some states may base taxation on where you live, while others may base it on where you work. Reciprocity agreements between states can also influence this. For example, Virginia, Maryland, and DC have an agreement that taxes are paid based on where you live for residents among these states. However, if you live in Delaware and work in Virginia, Virginia will tax that income. Therefore, research on reciprocity agreements for the specific states involved is crucial before moving .

4. Nonresident and Part-Year Resident Taxation: Some states, such as Massachusetts, allow part-year residents to claim a credit for taxes paid to other jurisdictions. However, nonresidents cannot claim this credit. If you move to a new state but continue to work in Massachusetts, for instance, you would still owe Massachusetts income tax for that income even after establishing residency in the new state. The credit for taxes paid to other jurisdictions is limited to the smaller of Massachusetts income tax on the income reported to the other jurisdiction or the actual tax paid to that jurisdiction .

5. Part-Year Resident Tax Forms: If you move mid-year, you may need to file a part-year resident tax form for the year of the move. For example, if you move from New Hampshire to Massachusetts, you would need to file a Form 1-NR/PY for that year, reporting income as a part-year resident of Massachusetts .

These are general guidelines, and specific tax situations can vary greatly depending on individual circumstances and the states involved. It's always advisable to consult with a tax professional for personalized advice when considering a change in state residency.

question: Can increasing my tax withholding from my full-time job cover FICA taxes for my freelance work?
answer:
Yes, increasing your tax withholding from your full-time job can help cover the amount owed for self-employment taxes from your freelance work. When you are self-employed, you are responsible for paying self-employment taxes, which serve a similar purpose to the Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) taxes paid by employees and employers for Social Security and Medicare. Self-employment taxes are mandated under the Self-Employment Contributions Act (SECA) and have equivalent rates to FICA taxes, combining both the employer and employee portions .

To cover these self-employment taxes, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) allows you to either make quarterly estimated tax payments or increase the withholding on your W-2 job to cover the expected tax liability from your freelance work. You are supposed to pay at least 90% of your tax liability during the year through increased withholding or quarterly estimated payments. If this is your first year of having to pay self-employment tax, you may qualify for a 'safe harbor' exception and avoid an underpayment penalty if your withholding covers at least 100% of your tax liability from the previous year, provided your income was not over $150,000 . 

It's important to make sure your combined payments—through withholding or estimated payments—cover both your income tax and your self-employment tax liabilities. Keep in mind that self-employment tax includes 12.4% for Social Security on your net income up to a certain threshold, which adjusts yearly based on inflation, and 2.9% for Medicare tax on all your net income with no limit .

Please make sure to consult with a tax professional for advice tailored to your specific situation, as tax laws can change and personal circumstances can influence the best approach to take.
ground_truth: Technically you owe 'self-employment' taxes not FICA taxes because they are imposed under a different law, SECA. However, since SE taxes are by design exactly the same rates as combining the two halves of FICA (employer and employee) it is quite reasonable to treat them as equivalent. SE taxes (and income tax also) are based on your net self-employment income, after deducting business expenses (but not non-business items like your home mortgage, dependent exemptions, etc which factor only into income tax). You owe SE Medicare tax 2.9% on all your SE net income (unless it is under $400) adjusted down by 7.65% to compensate for the fact that the employer half of FICA is excluded from gross income before the employee half is computed. You owe SE Social Security tax 12.4% on your adjusted SE net income unless and until the total income subject to FICA+SECA, i.e. your W-2 wages plus your adjusted SE net income, exceeds a cap that varies with inflation and is $127,200 for 2017. OTOH if FICA+SECA income exceeds $200k single or $250k joint you owe Additional Medicare tax 0.9% on the excess; if your W-2 income (alone) exceeds this limit your employer should withhold for it. However the Additional Medicare tax is part of 'Obamacare' (PPACA) which the new President and Republican majorities have said they will 'repeal and replace'; whether any such replacement will affect this for TY 2017 is at best uncertain at this point. question: How to calculate my estimated taxes. 1099 MISC + Self Employment
answer:
To calculate your estimated taxes when you have a 1099 MISC and are self-employed, you should consider both your federal income tax and self-employment tax liabilities. Here's a simplified breakdown of the steps you should follow:

1. **Calculate your net self-employment income**: Subtract any business-related expenses from your gross income to find your net self-employment income.

2. **Estimate your annual income**: This amount will be your adjusted annual income, which can be determined by adding your self-employment net income to any other sources of income, and then subtracting any deductions or credits you expect to claim.

3. **Calculate self-employment tax**: The self-employment tax rate is 15.3%, representing both the employer and employee portions of Social Security and Medicare taxes (12.4% for Social Security and 2.9% for Medicare). You can calculate the annual self-employment tax by applying this rate to your net self-employment income.

4. **Calculate federal income tax**: Apply the appropriate tax rates to your estimated taxable income (adjusted income minus deductions and exemptions) to determine your federal income tax liability.

5. **Calculate quarterly taxes**: Divide both the self-employment tax and federal income tax amounts by four to find your quarterly estimated payments.

6. **Make payments using Form 1040-ES**: Send your combined quarterly payments (federal income tax and self-employment tax) using Form 1040-ES.

Additionally:

- Don't forget to account for a personal exemption and a standard deduction if you're not itemizing deductions. For tax years prior to 2018, the personal exemption was $4,050 and the standard deduction was $6,300 for single filers, making the combined total $10,350 .

- Consider using tools like an IRS-provided spreadsheet or tax software to help with these calculations. For example, the spreadsheet version of IRS form 1040 provided by a private individual might calculate the self-employment tax as well as income tax when you input your information on Schedule C .

Remember that this information is general advice and based on guidelines that could be outdated. For the most accurate and up-to-date calculations, you should refer to the current year's tax forms and instructions or consult with a tax professional. If you're in doubt or have specific circumstances that could affect your tax calculation, seeking professional advice is always the best option.
ground_truth: There is a shortcut you can use when calculating federal estimated taxes.  Some states may allow the same type of estimation, but I know at least one (my own--Illinois) that does not. The shortcut: you can completely base your estimated taxes for this year on last year's tax return and avoid any underpayment penalty.  A quick summary can be found here (emphasis mine): If your prior year Adjusted Gross Income was $150,000 or less, then   you can avoid a penalty if you pay either 90 percent of this year's   income tax liability or 100 percent of your income tax liability from   last year (dividing what you paid last year into four quarterly   payments). This rule helps if you have a big spike in income one year,   say, because you sell an investment for a huge gain or win the   lottery. If wage withholding for the year equals the amount of tax you   owed in the previous year, then you wouldn't need to pay estimated   taxes, no matter how much extra tax you owe on your windfall. Note that this does not mean you will not owe money when you file your return next April; this shortcut ensures that you pay at least the minimum allowed to avoid penalty. You can see this for yourself by filling out the worksheet on form 1040ES.  Line 14a is what your expected tax this year will be, based on your estimated income.  Line 14b is your total tax from last year, possibly with some other modifications.  Line 14c then asks you to take the lesser of the two numbers.  So even if your expected tax this year is one million dollars, you can still base your estimated payments on last year's tax.

question: What items are exempt from the VAT? [U.K.]
answer:
In the UK, most consumer goods are subject to VAT at the standard rate. However, there are exemptions and some items are zero-rated or have a reduced VAT rate. Examples of exempt or zero-rated items include:

- Most food sold in shops is zero-rated, except for some luxury foods.
- Food served in cafes/restaurants and some takeaway food is subject to VAT at the standard rate.
- Most paper books are zero-rated, but books that come with CDs may be an exception.
- Some services are exempt from VAT, such as insurance and some transactions with charities.

It is worth noting that there is a distinction between zero-rated and exempt items, but for consumers, this distinction may not be significant. Additionally, some small businesses and sole traders may not be VAT registered and therefore do not charge VAT, though they cannot reclaim VAT on the goods and services they purchase. Moreover, second-hand goods have special rules regarding VAT.

For non-UK residents, there is a "retail export scheme" that might allow for a refund on VAT, but there are certain conditions that must be met .

question: Should I make extra payments to my under water mortgage or increase my savings?
answer:
The decision between making extra payments on an underwater mortgage or increasing your savings depends on several factors, including the specifics of your financial situation, your investment goals, and your tolerance for risk.

The information found suggests that by making extra semi-monthly payments of $100 each, you could pay off your mortgage in 23 years instead of 30. This would save you a significant amount on interest over the life of the loan, reduce the time you're in debt, and free up cash flow sooner for other investments or expenses .

However, there are also arguments for why you might want to increase your savings instead:

1. Liquidity: By increasing your savings, you have more liquid assets available to you, which can be useful in case of emergencies or opportunities that require quick access to cash.

2. Investment Return: If you can invest your savings in something that yields a higher return than the interest rate of your mortgage, your savings can potentially grow faster than the amount you would save on interest by paying down the mortgage early.

3. Tax Considerations: In some nations, such as the United States, mortgage interest is tax-deductible, which could affect the net benefit of paying off the mortgage sooner.

Ultimately, the decision also depends on your comfort level with debt, your other financial commitments, and future financial goals. It could be beneficial to speak with a financial advisor who can provide guidance based on a comprehensive review of your financial situation.

In making this decision, take into account that the greatest savings from making extra mortgage payments occur at the beginning of the mortgage term. If you've already been paying your mortgage for a while, the leverage obtained from pre-paying will be less than it would have been at the start . Additionally, you should consider the stability of your income, whether you can sustain higher payments without hardship, and how prepared you are to handle life's unexpected expenses.

Some strategies, like making one extra payment entirely to the principal at the beginning of each year on a 30-year mortgage, have been suggested to significantly reduce the amortization period and overall interest paid. However, the actual amount saved and the benefits of such strategies will vary depending on individual circumstances.

Given these points, both options have their merits and potential drawbacks. Weighing these factors against your personal financial goals and discussing with a professional may help you make the best decision for your situation.
ground_truth: I'd pile up as much cash as you can in a savings account - you will need money for the move (even if it's just gas money) and it's going to be hard to predict where house prices are going so you might or might not be underwater when it comes time to sell the house. Once you're actually in the process of selling the house, you can figure out if you can (or need to) use the savings to cover the shortfall, closing costs or if you just built up a little wealth during the time you put the money aside.

question: Am I considered in debt if I pay a mortgage?
answer: Yes, if you have a mortgage, you are considered to be in debt. A mortgage is a type of debt where someone lends you money to buy a house, which you are then obligated to pay back, so you have debt. Mortgages are secured by the property, meaning the lender can take possession of the house if you fail to repay the loan. It is not uncommon for people to have debts like mortgages, and having a mortgage does not necessarily mean you have a negative net worth, especially if you have equity in the house and other assets .
ground_truth: "The statistic you cited comes from the Federal Reserve Board's Survey of Consumer Finances, a survey that they do every three years, most recently in 2013.  This was reported in the September 2014 issue of the Federal Reserve Bulletin.  They list the percentage of Americans with any type of debt as 74.5 in 2013, down slightly from 74.9 in 2010. The Bulletin also has a table with a breakdown of the types of debt that people have, and primary residence mortgages are at the top of the list.  So the answer is yes, the 75% statistic includes Americans with home mortgages.* The bigger question is, are you really ""in debt"" if you have a home mortgage?  The answer to that is also yes.  When you take out a mortgage, you really do own the house.  You decide who lives there, you decide what changes you are going to make to it, and you are responsible for the upkeep.  But the mortgage debt you have is secured by the house.  This means that if you refuse to pay, the bank is allowed to take possession of the house.  They don't even get the ""whole"" house, though; they will sell it to recoup their losses, and give you back whatever equity you had in the house after the loan is satisfied. Is it good debt?  Many people think that if you are borrowing money to purchase an appreciating asset, the debt is acceptable.  With this definition, a car loan is bad, credit card debt is very bad, and a home mortgage might be okay.  Even Dave Ramsey, radio host and champion of the debt-free lifestyle, is not opposed to home mortgages.  Home mortgages allow people to purchase a home that they would otherwise be unable to afford. * Interestingly, according to the bulletin appendix, credit card balances were only included as debt for the survey purposes if there was a balance after the most recent bill was paid, not including purchases made after the bill.  So people that do not carry a balance on their credit card were not considered ""in debt"" in this statistic."

"I think you're thinking that ""in debt"" doesn't just mean ""owes a debt"" but somehow means ""owes more debt in total than the assets"". That condition, owing money without offsetting assets, is ""having a negative net worth"". If you have a mortgage then you have a debt and you are in debt. You may have a positive net worth, if you have equity in the house and your car and such like, and have cash in the bank. You may have a negative net worth if you owe more than you own. But either way you are technically in debt. Knowing that, it's not surprising that 75% of Americans are in debt. It's surprising that 25% are not. They have no credit card, no car loan, no mortgage, no line of credit, no student loans. Is it because they've paid all that off? Or because they are deadly poor and own nothing and can't be lent anything? You can't just say it's bad to have debt. It's bad to have too much debt, to have a negative net worth, to be in the habit of borrowing to finance a lifestyle you can't actually afford, and so on. But it's perfectly normal to have a debt or two. That's how our system mostly works."
Yes.   A mortgage is a kind of debt.  Someone lends you money to buy your house, and you owe them the money, so you have debt.

Yes, a mortgage is debt.  It's unique in that you have a house which should be worth far more than the mortgage. After the mortgage crisis, many found their homes under water i.e. worth less than the mortgage.  The word debt is a simple noun for money owed, it carries no judgement or negative connotation except when it's used to buy short lived items with money one doesn't have.  Aside from my mortgage, I get a monthly credit card bill which I pay in full. That's debt too, only it carried no interest and rewards me with 2% cash back. Many people would avoid this as it's still debt.

If you owe money to someone else then you are in debt, at least in the common meaning of the word.  What you happen to own, or what you spent that money on doesn't alter that fact. Are people considered in debt if their only 'debt' is the mortgage/loan for their house, or are these people excluded from the statistic? The only way to answer that for sure is to look at who compiled the statistic and exactly what methodology they used.

"Mortgage is a (secured) debt, a combination of a promissory note, and a security interest providing the mortage holder a secured interest in the property. Yes, you are ""in debt"". But that depends upon whether you define the term ""in debt"" as a debt appearing on the balance sheet, or the net of assets - liabilities is less than zero, whether you have a ""debt"" expense on the income statement (budget), or whether the net of income - expenses is less than zero. One person might look at their budget, find the (monthly) mortgage payment listed, and judge that they have a debt payment, and thus are ""in debt"". Or they might look at their expenses, find they exceed their income, and judge that they are ""in debt"". Another person might look at their balance sheet, compare assets to liabilities, and only say they were ""in debt"" when their liabilities exceeded their assets. Some people view mortgage debt as ""good debt"", as they view certain debts as ""good"" and others as ""bad"". Trust me, having a high mortgage payment (higher 30% of your net income) is hard, and over 40% is bad. Consider you balance sheet and your income statement.  On your balance sheet, the house appears on the ""asset"" side with an (estimated) value, while the ""mortgage"" (really, the promissory note part of the mortgage) appears on the ""liability"" side. On your income statement, your house does not appear on the income side, but the mortgage (promissory note) payment appears on the expense side. So, you clearly have both a ""liability"" with a clearly-defined value and an ""expense"" with a clearly-defined payment. But do you have an ""asset""? According to an accountant, you have an ""asset"" and a ""liability"". But you do not have a business asset that is producing revenue (income), nor do you have a business asset that can be amortized and expensed to reduce taxable income. When we think about an asset, does the word have the connotation of some thing with value, something that produces income?  Well, by that measure, a house only provides income when we rent it out, and only has value when we consider selling it. As millions of families discovered during the housing (price) collapse, when the market price of your ""asset"" falls substantially, your personal financial status can fall negative and you can be ""broke""."

"The expression ""in debt"" when talking about a person's financial affairs means that the sum of debit balances on all accounts exceeds the sum of credit balances on all accounts.    A mortgage account is not excluded from that. This definition also does not consider whether any of the debt is secured, or ownership of assets (shares, property, chattels, etc).   So, someone with a mortgage of one million dollars for a home that is worth two million is in debt by one million dollars, until they they sell the home (for that amount) and pay down the mortgage. That means ""in debt"" is not necessarily a statement about net worth."

question: AVS Address Verification System of BOTH Credit and Debit Cards - WHERE, HOW?
answer:
The Address Verification Service (AVS) is a system used in conjunction with zip code and billing address information to verify the address with the billing address on file with the issuing bank of a credit or debit card. AVS is used as a web or phone service and does not use the credit card's magnetic stripe. Instead, it relies on the information that the bank has on file to confirm transactions.

As per the document, the types of information stored on the credit card magnetic stripe may include the account number, name, expiration date, card-specific details, and a discretionary section. However, it generally does not include much in terms of address information. When a false zip code is provided, a purchase may be rejected, as the AVS system might not be able to match the provided information with that on file at the bank.

Furthermore, AVS is utilized differently based on the transaction context. For example, zip codes entered at pay-at-the-pump gas stations for AVS are reportedly not used for marketing purposes, particularly under the regulation of certain states such as California, as long as the information is only used for AVS purposes .

While AVS can verify numeric address parts such as address number, apartment number, and zipcode, American Express can also verify cardholder names. The capability to validate certain pieces of information will depend on what the individual issuing bank chooses to support since there is no master database of every cardholder. A "verify-only" transaction that returns AVS values without charging the card is supported by some processors but requires an "approved merchant account" . 

In summary, AVS confirms the billing address information provided during a transaction with the cardholder's information on file with the bank. It helps prevent unauthorized use of a card and is also a measure against fraud.
ground_truth: "Parts of what you want are possible, but taken as a whole, you're out of luck. First of all, there is no master database of every cardholder in the country.  The only way to check if information is correct is to ask the issuing bank.  The AVS system is a way to automate doing so, but it's possible to call the bank directly and verbally verify the address.   That means you're subject to the whims of what the issuing bank chooses to support.  Banks that are part of the Visa and MasterCard networks generally only verify the numeric parts (address, apartment number, zipcode).  AmEx can also verify the cardholder name.  But if the bank doesn't have support for validating something, you can't validate it. Separately, there is a ""verify-only"" transaction which some processors support, which will do exactly what you want:  Return AVS values without ever charging the card.  However, processors require you to have the ""approved merchant account"" you don't want to have to have.  Without being a merchant, you shouldn't have access to other people's credit cards anyway.  Would you really want anyone in the country to be able to verify anyone else's address whenever they want? In short, whatever purpose you have for wanting this probably falls into one of three categories:"

question: How can I live outside of the rat race of American life with 300k?
answer:
To live outside the rat race of American life with $300,000, there are several strategies you might consider. Based on the contents of the file provided, it appears that avoiding the traditional 9-to-5 and consumer debt can be key factors in stepping away from that cycle. Additionally, leveraging remote work opportunities can facilitate mobility and reduce the need to participate in the daily commute, which is often associated with the rat race.

Investment is highlighted as another strategy to consider. Investing your capital with a goal to generate income can help to sustain your livelihood without the need to engage in the rat race. It's suggested to invest as if you're managing a university endowment, aiming for long-term growth and accounting for inflation. By withdrawing a prudent percentage of your investment annually, such as 5-7%, which on $300,000 would equate to $15,000-$21,000, you may be able to cover living expenses, although these figures will need to be adjusted for taxes and inflation .

Another avenue mentioned is real estate. With $300,000, you could potentially purchase two or three single-family dwellings or invest in multifamily housing or commercial real estate to generate rental income. Ensuring that you have good property management will be essential to minimize effort and attention required on your part while maintaining a consistent income stream .

The documents also caution about the volatility of investments and the potential for financial loss, emphasizing the need for careful consideration and possibly consultation with a financial mentor who can guide you through the process .

Finally, personal living choices, such as adopting a minimalist lifestyle or pursuing van life or narrowboat living, could allow you to live well within the potential income generated from your investments .

Keep in mind that these are foundational ideas, and a detailed plan should be tailored to your personal situation, accounting for various factors such as your cost of living, healthcare needs, personal preferences, and risk tolerance. It may also be beneficial to consult with a financial advisor to create a more precise and sustainable plan.
ground_truth: "So my read on the question is ""How do I invest 300k such that it earns me a 'living wage' without the ongoing grind inherent in most formal employment?""  Reading the other answers to date it looks like most of them are thinking in terms of investment accounts and trying to live off of the earnings from such.  I wanted to throw out a couple of alternative choices that may be worth considering... The first is real-estate investing.  $300k should allow you to pick up 2 or 3 single family dwellings with little or no mortgage.  Turning them into rentals placed with a good property management company should easily pay their expenses and provide a consistent income with minimal effort/attention from you.  Similar story with buying into multifamily housing or commercial real-estate. Your key concern here is picking the right market in which to buy and finding a reputable manager to handle the day to day issues on your behalf. Note that you are not overly concerned with the potential resale value of the property(s), but the probable rental income they can generate, these are separate concerns that may not align with each other. Second is buying/founding a business that has a general manager other than yourself.  Franchise ownership may be a potential option for you under the circumstances.  The key concern here is picking the business, location, and manager that make you comfortable in terms of the risk involved.  You need the place to make enough money to pay for itself and the salary of everyone working there, with enough left over for you to live on.  Sounds easy enough, but not so much in practice.  Generally you can expect at least a few years of being hands on and watching things very closely to make sure it is going the way you want it to.  Finding a mentor who has done this type of transition before to walk you through it would be strongly advised.  So would preparing yourself for a failure or two before you work out the exact combination of factors that work for you."

"The title of your question is quite different then the content.  The term ""Rat Race"" was coined in the 70's and refers to the endless cycle of working hard to consume more. No.  Pick some nice things and pay cash. Debt, especially consumer debt, causes a person (in effect) to work for a bank.  Avoiding debt will remove those feelings. Saving and investing also helps avoid those feelings.  There is profound satisfaction in watching ones account balances grow.  Once you see that your investment earnings can outpace your expenses, and then your salary you really feel like you are getting ahead.      Above all else giving is a paramount and often overlooked part of a person's financial life.  It causes one to be humble and recognize that most people, in this world, are less fortunate that us.  It avoids runaway provide that justifies purchases that we cannot afford.   So yea you can avoid the ""Rat Race"" and still work."

"An endowment is a large chunk of capital (i.e. money) held by  a university or other nonprofit.  It is meant to hold its value forever against inflation, and invested to generate income: from interest, dividends and appreciation.   They seem like a contradiction: closely scrutinized by Boards of Directors, managed to a high and accountable standard, closely regulated -- and yet, invested aggressively for growth: ignoring short-term volatility to get the highest growth long-term.  The law, UPMIFA (P for Prudent), requires growth investment, and says taking up to 7% of current value per year is prudent, even in down times when total value is shrinking.  On average, this lets the endowment grow with inflation.  7% is the high end of ""prudent"".  An endowment is watched, and the taken income is adjusted to keep the endowment healthy. 5% is very safe, assuming the endowment must pace inflation until the heat death of the universe. If you plan to die someday, drawing an extra 1-2% is appropriate.  There you go.  Invest like a university endowment, and count on up to 7% per year of income.  That's $21,000 a year. question: Claiming mileage allowances, what are the rules/guidelines?
answer:
The rules and guidelines for claiming mileage allowances in the context of commuting and transportation expenses are as follows:

1. Commuting expenses between your home and your main or regular place of work are considered personal commuting expenses and are not deductible. This applies regardless of the distance from home to work or if you work during the commute .

2. Regular W2 employees cannot deduct housing or transportation costs related to their employment. However, employers in the U.S. may offer Parking and/or Transit Flexible Spending Account (FSA) programs, known as Commuter Benefits FSA programs. These programs allow employees to defer up to $255 per month from their gross pay, tax-free, for parking and/or transit expenses, which include eligible expenses like bus and train passes or parking at a train or bus station. These contributions are subject to use-it or lose-it provisions and must be sponsored by the employer .

3. For personal car commuters, the main category eligible for pretax deduction is for paying for parking. IRS guidelines list Qualified Transportation Benefits, which include a ride in a commuter highway vehicle between the employee's home and workplace, a transit pass, qualified parking, and qualified bicycle commuting reimbursement. It should be noted that the exclusion for qualified bicycle commuting reimbursement is not available in any month the employee receives any of the other qualified transportation benefits .

When considering mileage allowances for business use of a personal vehicle, an employer-created Flexible Spending Account (FSA) can be used. Employees can contribute amounts to these accounts, with pre-tax income, deduct the contributions, and then withdraw the funds to cover their transportation expenses. This arrangement does not come through deductions on Schedule A but rather through the pretax income contributions to an FSA .

Please keep in mind that tax laws and guidelines can change, and it's always a good idea to consult with an accountant or refer to the official IRS guidelines for the most accurate and current information.

question: Tips for insurance coverage for one-man-teams
answer:
Here are some tips for insurance coverage for one-man teams, based on the information provided in the document:

1. Pay attention to tax considerations when evaluating health insurance premiums. If you are self-employed, note that health insurance premiums can be deducted on Line 29 of Form 1040 but only under certain conditions related to coverage eligibility through an employer or a spouse's employer. The ability to pay premiums with pre-tax dollars can affect the overall cost of insurance .

2. Explore options provided by professional and trade associations, as some offer group insurance plans at discounted rates, akin to COBRA coverage, but without the employer subsidy on premiums. Membership in organizations such as IEEE or ACM, which cater to professionals such as software developers, could provide access to insurance forms among other benefits .

3. Utilize resources such as credit unions, cooperatives, local chambers of commerce, and possibly faith-based non-insurance organizations that offer medical cost-sharing services to seek lower-cost insurance alternatives .

4. Understand that health insurance is regulated at the state level, which influences the options available to you. You might find a list of insurance companies or insurance of last resort options on your state’s official website .

Always consider your specific circumstances when determining the right insurance options for your one-man team. Factors such as your location, the nature of your self-employment, tax implications, and the benefits offered by different organizations will all play a part in finding suitable coverage.

So the self-employed person has to pay both the employer's share as well as the employee's share of Social Security and Medicare taxes on that money. Health insurance premiums can be deducted on Line 29 of Form 1040 but only for those months during which the Schedule C filer is neither  covered nor eligible to be covered by a subsidized health insurance plan maintained by an employer of the self-employed person (whose self-employment might be a sideline) or the self-employed person's spouse. In other words, just having the plan coverage available through the wife's employment, even though one disdains taking it, is sufficient to make a Line 29 deduction impermissible.  So, AGI is increased. Health insurance premiums can be deducted on Schedule A but only to the extent that they (together with other medical costs) exceed 10% of AGI. For many people in good health, this means no deduction there either. Thus, when comparing the premiums of health insurance policies, one should pay some attention to the tax issues too. Health insurance  through a spouse's employment might not be that bad a deal after all.

question: Vanguard ETF vs mutual fund
answer:
Vanguard ETFs and mutual funds are both investment options offered by Vanguard, but they have different characteristics and benefits.

Vanguard ETFs (Exchange-Traded Funds):
- They trade like stocks and can be bought and sold throughout the trading day at fluctuating market prices. 
- Vanguard ETFs are commission-free to Vanguard clients using Vanguard Brokerage Services. However, investors using other brokerage services may face commissions or other costs.
- ETFs do not allow for auto-investment of a fixed dollar amount since you typically must buy whole shares, which could make regular investing a bit more challenging if you have a specific budget in mind.
- Vanguard ETFs may serve as an alternative to mutual funds in certain retirement plans, like 401ks, where direct mutual fund investments aren't available, but brokerage options are present .

Vanguard Mutual Funds:
- Mutual funds are bought and sold at the end of the trading day at the net asset value (NAV) price, regardless of what time orders are placed.
- They often allow for the automatic investing of a fixed dollar amount, which can include fractional shares, thus making regular contributions easier to manage.
- Some Vanguard mutual funds, such as the Admiral Shares, have a lower expense ratio which is comparable to their ETF counterparts, but these often come with a minimum investment requirement.
- Mutual funds can be more convenient for those in the financial industry who have to request permission for every trade of equities or ETFs due to regulatory requirements. Mutual funds do not have this limitation, thus simplifying the investment process for these individuals .

In considering whether to choose a Vanguard ETF or mutual fund, investors must weigh factors such as transaction costs, investment minimums, convenience of investing, the ability to invest fixed amounts automatically, and whether they need to use more complex investment strategies like options trading or short selling which are available with ETFs. Additionally, if an investor starts with certain mutual funds and later wishes to convert to the Admiral Shares version, that conversion can be a non-taxable event, contrasting with potentially taxable events that occur when selling ETF shares to transition to mutual funds  .

It's important to note that for most retail investors, the limitations of mutual funds, such as no intra-day trading or options, may actually be beneficial as it discourages speculative behavior that may not align with long-term financial goals. Nonetheless, many brokers now offer a selection of ETFs with no transaction fees, which might make ETFs more cost-effective, especially large ETFs with narrow spreads . 

Remember to consider your investment style, financial goals, and whether you value the flexibility and trading advantages of ETFs over the simplicity and automatic investing benefits of mutual funds.

question: Calculation, timing, and taxes related to profit distribution of an S-corp?
answer:
Profit distribution in an S-Corp is subject to certain IRS regulations which distinguish between salary and distributions to ensure reasonable compensation for services provided to the S-Corp. For instance, the IRS evaluated a case (Watson v. Commissioner) where an S-Corp owner, the sole employee, paid himself a salary far below what was customary for the industry, choosing instead to take most of the S-Corp profits as distributions. The IRS re-characterized some distribution amounts to salary up to a reasonable level based on industry standards, which, in Watson's case, was $93,000 out of a total of around $400,000 earned by the corporation. Beyond this level, the remaining funds could be taken as distributions which are not generally subject to payroll taxes.

It's worth noting that the reasoning for the differentiation between salary and distributions in this case was because the individual was not the sole person generating revenue, implying that a sole revenue-producer might be expected to account for more of the income as salary.

Any decision on how to pay oneself as an owner of an S-Corp should be based on professional advice (ideally both legal and accounting), as this could provide a strong defense if the IRS audits the S-Corp's financial arrangements. It's critical not to rely solely on non-professional advice found in articles or forums on the internet when making such decisions .

Moreover, for an individual who is the sole employee and revenue producer of an S-Corp, it may be hard to justify that the corporation has earned more than what their work is worth; therefore, the IRS may expect a large portion of the S-Corp's profits to be attributed to their salary. Specifically, when the amounts fall below the FICA Social Security limits, separating salary and distributions may be viewed as an attempt to evade FICA tax.

Tax laws and precedents are complex, so professional advice is crucial to ensuring compliance and avoiding potential issues with the IRS. In terms of timing, salary must be consistently paid throughout the year, matching standard payroll practices, while distributions can typically occur at times when the S-Corp has made a profit and after reasonable compensation has been paid.

For tax specifics related to S-Corps and their distributions, consider consulting with a tax professional who can provide personalized, legally sound advice based on the latest tax regulations and case law.

question: United States Treasury Not Endorsing Checks

The document indicates that there is indeed no formal "United States Treasury" endorsement on Treasury-issued checks. The reasons stated are practical—there is no expectation for someone from the Treasury to be endorsing checks by hand, and at most, one might expect a stamp, given that no individual would sign all the checks. It further outlines that you cannot have the check returned for proper endorsement unless you have a serious reason to believe someone other than the Treasury cashed your check. Moreover, it was clarified that an endorsement is often not required as long as the name on the check matches the name on the account to which it is deposited, although individual banks may have stricter rules .

In addition, the document sarcastically alludes to modern banking regulations like Check 21 and the Patriot Act. These acts have given the government and banks increased control over financial transactions, essentially stating that money in bank accounts is more like a "credit" to your account with the bank, which they can manage as they wish. Due to these regulations, banks are required to identify the parties in any banking transaction, effectively removing anonymity from banking transactions, among other things. As a result, the document suggests that the absence of a Treasury endorsement on checks is a reflection of these modern financial regulations .

question: Diversify my retirement investments with a Roth IRA
answer:
Diversifying your retirement investments using a Roth IRA can be a very wise decision, particularly if you expect to be in a higher tax bracket during retirement or if you are currently unable to directly contribute to a Roth IRA due to income limits. One common strategy mentioned in the document I reviewed is a "backdoor Roth IRA contribution," which involves making a non-deductible contribution to a Traditional IRA and then converting it to a Roth IRA. This method can circumvent the income limits associated with direct Roth IRA contributions and can be a tax-free process if there were no previous pre-tax money in Traditional or other IRAs. Additionally, a Roth IRA can be a good place to hold investments that generate income, such as bonds or REITs, as they are typically taxed at the income rate and the Roth IRA allows for tax-free growth and withdrawals in retirement .

Moreover, it's worth noting that conversions to a Roth IRA must be completed by December 31st of the tax year. However, the document does mention that recharacterization — reversing a Roth conversion — has a deadline of October 15th of the year following the original conversion. This recharacterization can provide some flexibility, but requires careful tax planning and is often best done when tax brackets are low .

Finally, the document emphasizes the importance of starting early with your retirement savings since the longer you wait, the less time your money has to grow. Given the rules of thumb from Fidelity mentioned in the document, you should evaluate your current retirement savings and contribution plans to ensure you are on track to meet your retirement goals. The combination of a Roth IRA with your other retirement investment strategies can help you diversify your portfolio and manage your tax liabilities effectively .

That way, if the investment works out, you have more money in the account that won't ever be taxed. We can talk about the possible risks of certain kinds of investments, but this is not an appropriate forum to recommend for or against them specifically. Healthcare stocks are subject to political risk in the current regulatory climate. BRICs are subject to political risks regarding the political and business climate in the relevant nations, and the growth of their economies need not correspond with growth in the companies you hold in your portfolio. Energy stocks are subject to the world economic climate and demand for oil, unless you're talking alternative-energy stocks, which are subject to political risk regarding their subsidies and technological risk regarding whether or not their technologies pan out. It is worth pointing out that any ETF you invest in will have a prospectus, and that prospectus will contain a section discussing the risks which could affect your investment. Read it before investing! :)

question: Why do people buy US dollars on the black market?
answer:
People might buy US dollars on the black market for several reasons:

1. **Access to Hard Currency**: In countries with currency controls or economic instability, the black market may be the only place where individuals can obtain foreign currency like US dollars, which are often seen as a more stable store of value.

2. **Exchange Rate Advantages**: The official exchange rate might be fixed at an unrealistic level, making black market rates more favorable for buying dollars. People might obtain more dollars per unit of local currency on the black market.

3. **Avoiding Restrictions**: Governments might impose restrictions on the amount of foreign currency that individuals can buy legally. The black market provides a way to bypass these limits.

4. **Privacy and Anonymity**: Transactions on the black market are generally done without official oversight, which means that they can be done anonymously. This can appeal to those wishing to avoid scrutiny over their financial dealings.

5. **Speed and Convenience**: The black market can offer quicker and more convenient transactions, free from the bureaucracy and limitations of official channels.

6. **Illegal Activities**: The black market is also used for money laundering and other illegal activities because it operates outside the regulated financial system.

It's important to note that dealing in the black market can be illegal and risky, with potential consequences including counterfeit currency, legal penalties, and the risk of theft or fraud.

Countries like Iran or Venezuela, with a managed exchange rate, set their exchange rates at a higher value than the market accepts. Such market expectations may be influenced by poor government management, interventions into markets (such as nationalising businesses) or general instability / scarcity. The governments act to manage that uncertainty by limiting the availability of foreign exchange and pegging the exchange rate.   Since there is an inadequate supply of trusted foreign currency people turn to informal exchanges in order to hedge their currency risk.  This creates a negative feedback loop.  People in government who have access to foreign exchange start to trade on informal markets, pocketing the difference in the official and unofficial rates.  The increasing gap between the two rates drives increasing informal market exchange and can result in speculative bubbles. Driving instability (or economic contradiction) is that the massive and increasing difference between the official and market exchange rates becomes a powerful form of rent for government officials. This drives further state-led rent-seeking behaviour and causes the economy to become even more unstable. If you're interested in a more formal academic study of how such parallel markets in currency arise, ""Zimbabwe’s Black Market for Foreign Exchange"" by Albert Makochekanwa at the University of Pretoria is a useful source."

question: Pros and Cons of Interest Only Loans
answer:
Interest-only loans provide several advantages and disadvantages, which can be significant depending on individual circumstances and the state of the housing market.

Pros:
1. Increased cash flow: By paying only the interest and not the principle, you can increase your monthly cash flow. This can be particularly advantageous for investors who have their investment loans on interest-only terms, as it allows them to allocate excess cash flow into offset accounts linked to the investment loans, providing a financial buffer .

2. Investment opportunities: If you are disciplined, you could invest the money saved from the lower monthly payments at a higher return rate. For example, if you can invest at a return of 8% over 10 years, you could accumulate significant additional wealth compared to paying both interest and principal .

3. Tax benefits: Wealthier homeowners may benefit from tax breaks and the opportunity to leverage cheap money for investment purposes .

Cons:
1. No principal reduction: During the interest-only period, you do not pay off any of the principal, which means that you are entirely reliant on the property's value increasing for your equity to grow .

2. Higher risk: The risk of financial difficulty increases if you are overextended, as you aren't building equity unless property prices go up. Also, a slight change in financial circumstances could lead to serious trouble if you don't have a financial buffer .

3. Higher interest rates: Interest rates for interest-only loans are typically higher, since they are considered higher risk to the bank due to the fact that the principal is not being reduced. The rates are usually an eighth- to a half-percentage point higher than on fully amortized jumbo loans .

4. Tougher qualification and fewer lenders: Qualifying for interest-only loans is generally more challenging, and fewer lenders offer them because of the increased risk to the bank .

It is important to carefully consider these factors and your own financial situation before deciding on an interest-only loan.

question: Why should one only contribute up to the employer's match in a 401(k)?
answer:
One should only contribute up to the employer's match in a 401(k) primarily because the matching funds are essentially free money, giving what is effectively a 100% return on those contributions. For example, if you deposit $1000 and your employer matches that $1000, you effectively have $2000 in your 401(k).

Beyond the employer match, your investment options in a 401(k) are typically more limited than those available in an Individual Retirement Account (IRA). Additionally, the costs associated with a 401(k) can be considerable and are generally higher than those for IRA accounts. After taking advantage of the employer match, the restricted investment choices and higher costs in a 401(k) mean that your opportunity for returns is lower compared to investing in an account with a broader range of investment options and lower fees, such as an IRA.
ground_truth: The matching funds are free money, so it is a very good idea to take that money off the table. Vesting schedules mean that the employer match isn't yours to keep immediately, but rather after some time; usually in chunks.) Beyond the employer match, you need to consider what is available for investment in a 401(k).  Typically, your options are more limited then in an IRA.  The cost of the 401(k) should be considered, as it isn't trivial for most.  (The specifics will of course vary, but in large IRA accounts are cheaper.) So, it's about the opportunity costs.  Up to the employer match, it doesn't matter as much that your investment choices are more limited in a 401(k), because you're getting 100% return just on the matching funds.  Once that is exhausted, you have more opportunity for returns, due to having more options available to you, by going with an account that provides more choices. The overall principle here is that you have to look at the whole picture.  This is similar to the notion that you should pay-down your high interest debt before investing, because from the perspective of investing the interest you're paying represent a loss, or negative return on investment, since money is going out of your accounts.  Specific to your question, you have to consider the various types of investment vehicles available to you.  It is not just about 401(k) and IRA accounts.  You may also consider a straight brokerage account, a savings account, CDs, etc.  The costs and returns that you can typically expect are your guides through the available choices.

So, put enough into your 401(k) to get the match, then max out IRA contributions to give you access to more and better investment options, then go back to your 401(k) until you top that out as well, assuming you have that much available to invest for retirement.

question: What is the easiest way to back-test index funds and ETFs?
answer:
The easiest way to back-test index funds and ETFs (Exchange-Traded Funds) is by using historical data and software that allows for simulation of investment strategies over a specific period. Here is a simplified step-by-step guide you could follow:

1. **Gather Historical Data**: Obtain the historical price data for the index funds and ETFs you want to back-test. This data can usually be found on financial websites, through investment platforms, or via APIs that provide stock market data.

2. **Choose a Back-testing Platform**: There are various types of software available that can help with back-testing, from simple spreadsheets like Microsoft Excel to specialized back-testing platforms like QuantConnect, Backtrader, and TradingView. These platforms generally offer comprehensive tools and allow you to simulate trading strategies using past data.

3. **Define Your Strategy**: Determine the rules of your investment strategy. This includes entry and exit points, position sizing, rebalancing frequency, and other relevant criteria.

4. **Simulate Trades**: Input your strategy parameters into the back-testing platform and run the simulation. The software will apply your strategy to the historical data and execute hypothetical trades according to your rules.

5. **Analyze the Results**: After running the simulation, analyze the performance metrics provided by the back-testing software. Common metrics include total return, annualized return, maximum drawdown, Sharpe ratio, and other risk/return indicators.

6. **Adjust and Repeat**: Based on the results, you may want to adjust your strategy and back-test again. This could involve changing the timing of trades, adjusting stop-loss levels, or diversifying with additional assets.

It's important to note that back-testing has limitations. Past performance is not indicative of future results, and simulated trades do not take into account factors such as market impact, liquidity constraints, and changes in market conditions that can affect the outcome of real-world trades.

question: In US, is it a good idea to hire a tax consultant for doing taxes?
answer:
Whether it's a good idea to hire a tax consultant in the US depends on several factors, including the complexity of your tax situation, your familiarity with tax laws, and the amount of time you're willing to invest in doing your taxes.

Here are some situations where it might be beneficial to hire a tax consultant:

1. **Complex Financial Situations**: If you have multiple income streams, investments, rental properties, or you own a business, your tax situation may be more complex, and a tax consultant can help you navigate the details.

2. **Life Changes**: Major life events like getting married, divorced, having a child, or retiring can affect your tax status. A consultant can advise on how these life changes impact your taxes.

3. **New Tax Laws**: If there have been recent changes to tax laws that you're not familiar with, a consultant who's up-to-date with the latest tax legislation can ensure you comply with the new rules.

4. **Deductions and Credits**: You may not be aware of all the deductions and credits you're entitled to. Tax consultants can help identify these to potentially reduce your tax liability.

5. **Avoiding Mistakes**: Mistakes on tax returns can lead to audits, penalties, and fines. A tax consultant can help minimize these risks.

6. **Audit Representation**: If you're facing an audit, a tax consultant can represent you before the IRS, which can be incredibly beneficial.

7. **Saving Time**: Doing your taxes can be time-consuming, especially if your finances are complex. Hiring a consultant can save you time.

On the other hand, if your tax situation is straightforward (e.g., you only have a single source of income and take the standard deduction), you may be able to easily file your taxes using online software without the need for a consultant.

Ultimately, the decision should be based on your specific circumstances and whether the potential benefits outweigh the costs of hiring a professional. It's advisable to consider the complexity of your tax situation, your level of understanding of tax laws, how much your time is worth, and whether you're comfortable preparing your own taxes.
